Author: jorian#4555
Content: in before Alright angryness: #komodo-team

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: @jl777c where can I read up on the difficulty algo related to notaries? because I'd imagine malicious notaries may be able to abuse their mining priviliges?

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: btw, how does the community veto / kick notaries? can a vote be called?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notaries get to mine at easy diff once per 65 blocks

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with 64 notaries there is room for some underperforming notaries, the annual election will sort that out

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a single notary couldnt really do much to abuse their mining, a 1.6% attack isnt very strong

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: certianly if all the notaries are compromised, then we have a problem

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but a lot of notaries are known community members

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: the ratio of notary mined blocks to standard is 3:1 but 64/65 blocks a notary will get a chance to mine one, how does that play out?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the notaries add delayes to their mining where longer and logner random delays are added the loser the external mining percentage gets

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: is there a document on this algorithm?

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: or something i could search for

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a dishonest notary could get 20% more blocks, but they would be found out

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the code is the documentation in this case:

Author: jl777c#5810
ProficieNt#3097
Content: if honest notaries should be mining 1.17% of the blocks, you're saying a dishonest notary could mine 1.4% of the blocks but it would be obvious to the public

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all the notary statistics are closely monitored by the notaries

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: doing such things would disqualify a notary

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: okay and if someone, or a group of people, start abusing the network the community could hardfork? or is there a protocol level way to kick notaries

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if majority of notaries area compromised, a hardfork seems the only safe way to correct things

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: if around 5 start performing selfish mining attacks and trying to gain more control?

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: how could they be dealt with?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: most notary operators are known community members

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: loss of reputation would be a big loses, and wouldnt it take closer to 20 notaries to do selfih mining, unless you mean the 1.4%

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: notary corruption is unlikely and in any case it is visbiel and correctable if the unlikely happens

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: correctable through a hard fork though?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes,we have a sheduled annual hardfork

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and we use it to activate new consusus changes at the same time

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: okay, and if someone is caught buying votes they are disqualified through social consensus?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: sometimes there is an in-between hardfork

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it seems it is impossible to detect buying of votes

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: and if KMD holder wants to give his voting decision to someone else, that in  a way is his decision

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there are all sorts of doomsday theories how all the notaries will be planted zombies and such nonsense. the reality is that the community makes a serious decision about who the 64 are, as the last elections showed

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: okay, fair enough. how do asset chains pay for notarization? As I understand, that is currently a manual process?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes, notaries need to get the coin being notarized and the KMD to cover the notarizing txfees (but not the BTC txfees that are already paid)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: an the notaries have to start running the coin, and the notarize it. there is no way to automate that, so it is necessarily a manual pricess

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: I'm just wondering what the reason for requiring 13 notaries to reach consensus? Would it not be possible to let anyone notarize and it to just be a part of the normal mining process?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: where is the incentive for them to notarize?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: without a decent number notarizing how to know it is very likely the mainchain?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: without knowing who the noataries are how would we know who is notarizing? and if they are not known then there is no reputation loss, to prevent playing games

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so, yes it is possible, but we have a public election process, etc. not sure what is gained from  anonymous randome notarizers

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it seem you are trying to make problems out of non-issues

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content:
1) To secure their chain of PoW, with SCs you could attach a bounty to proving notarization.
2) Surely you can have individuals optionally run the Bitcoin blockchain. If someone tries to fake that Merkle tree, the nodes with the BTC chain can send a proof showing that the merkle was invalid and the others can ignore the previous notarization. (not sure how this works but might help: https://blog.kyber.network/chain-relays-or-a-practical-approach-for-cross-chain-trades-d0d7003f266b)
3) We build systems that don't need trust because they are more efficient and resilient.

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: if you make notarization anonymous using incentives, you can support many more chains and without any middleman handling the money

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: https://media.consensys.net/linking-the-chains-with-btc-relay-5ffd2c8248

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: i thoguht btc relay was discontinued, the daily cost of ETH txfee was $10,000+ or something like that

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nice theoretical solutions are nice, but until  it is proven you can get regular BTC notarizations with miners upfronting the BTC and somehow coordinating with each other, it is unproven

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: trusting  BTC relay to exist is not any better

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: maybe not the BTC cost

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: but from other chains into KMD

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: that should be automated and can be

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: such enhancements are not prohibited and likely will be done

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: and why do the miners need to coordinate?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the BTC fees are the big hurdle

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: you will trust a single anonymous notarizer? doesnt that open up a lot more minority attack vectors

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: you dont trust anyone, you trust the BTC blockchains

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: a losing fork can be notarized by a single miner? seems very weak

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: *blockchain

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: look, the problem with BTC is its slow so yes its not perfect

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: but smaller coins into MKD

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: *KMD

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: you should be able to anonymize and automate the proccess

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: any blockchain is always in flux, also we are believing that BTC tx when it goes into the mempool

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the odds of it not getting eventually confirmed are very small

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: thiough it is of course better when there isnt a mempool backlog

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: okay, forget BTC

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: we are trying to make Komodo the best it can be

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: so, it seems that automatic notarization on KMD is relatively straight forward and would be a big bonus to the network? it decreases a central reliance on notary nodes and makes the protocol more resilient

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: not sure it is relatively straight forward, but I would definitely consider such a pull request as long as there are no issues found by the anonymous and lack of N nodes in agreement

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: where do you see problems? the main pre-requisite is a scripting language / smart contracts so these chains can manage their notarizations

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: the contract has a function submitNotarization() which takes a block header / proof as an argument. It has a second function submitChallenge() which lets someone challenge a previous submission by submitting a block that shows an earlier inclusion of the notarization TX. If they do this, the previous notarization is removed and the new notarization is accepted

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: that's probably a naive SC implementation but you guys are the devs here so you tell me üòõ

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: @jl777c the current solution requires notaries to run every child chain, right?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: yes

Author: xRobeSx#5136
Content: @ProficieNt I‚Äôm not sure this helps, but I saw you mentioning everyone should be able to notarize. Technically anyone can setup a tier 2 Notary Node network and notarize whatever coins they wanna run to KMD. So technically you could run your own private NN‚Äôs to notarize your private assetchain to KMD for example. As for notarizing to BTC, as James said it‚Äôs very expensive so that‚Äôs why the KMD team covers paying the btc fees for the elected (tier 1) NN‚Äôs.

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: @jl777c this will pose great scalability issues, issues that trustless notarization will solve

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: @xRobeSx but that mechanism still requires you to trust someone. someone who probably isnt as trustworthy as the current notaries

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: im suggesting a mechanism by which you trust no one, in the sense that anyone can be a notary and prove if someone is disingenuous

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: add a few economic incentives and you've got a highly scalable protocol

Author: xRobeSx#5136
Content: I‚Äôm just saying in the scenario I just mentioned, you wouldn‚Äôt have to trust the notarization to KMD as you could do it yourself with your own NN‚Äôs. As for the KMD -> BTC notarization of the previous, you‚Äôd be trusting just the elected NN‚Äôs

Author: xRobeSx#5136
Content: I‚Äôm not trying to persuade your thinking, just bringing up another angle, as I don‚Äôt think many people realize there can be sub NN tiers

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: this is all in the realm of possible, the subNN is not enabled yet, it is needing a bit more work

Author: xRobeSx#5136
Content: Oh thanks for the clarification James. I thought it was possible and @SHossain was using a subNN to notarize the scaling chains

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it is called a notarizing testnet

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: for testing, not mainchain use (yet)

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but yes, the notarization group can be customized with an external JSON config file

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: @xRobeSx are we building a blokchain or an SQL database? why should my network participants trust me to solely manage notarization?

Author: xRobeSx#5136
Content: I'm not saying just you. You could setup 1 private NN and maybe release documentation for anyone using your coin to notarize it?  Maybe you could make the first assetchain that has decentralized notarizations üòÉ

Content: dont have a use for an asset chain personally haha

Author: ProficieNt#3097
Content: Komodo is supposed to provide utility to small PoW chains, not have small PoW chains build features for Komodo üòõ
